Award.AwardTitle: CREST: Nanotechnology Center for Biomedical and Energy-Driven Systems and Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The University of Puerto Rico, Mayagüez (UPRM) seeks to integrate education and research by establishing a Nanotechnology Center for Biomedical and Energy-Driven Systems and Applications (NCBEDSA). The overall Center strategy will secure national competitiveness of UPRM in the area of materials engineering research and nanotechnology. The Center?s mission is to integrate ongoing research and education efforts in engineered nanostructured materials focused on two strategic areas for the institution and the island: biomedical and energy-driven systems. Within this framework, the NCBEDSA faculty will broaden and strengthen graduate and undergraduate education throughout the institution by supporting existing and upcoming pertinent graduate programs and developing new ones. This will form a cadre of lifelong-learning materials professionals with a robust interdisciplinary training. To achieve the aforementioned goals the Center will be organized into four interdisciplinary research groups (IGRs) and one interdisciplinary educational group (IEG). The Center?s transformative research focuses on fundamental and applied aspects of nanomaterials encompassing: IGR1) multifunctional nanoparticles for magnetically actuated siRNA delivery; IGR2) quantum dot systems for cancer therapy; IGR3) nanoporous materials for separations and catalysis; and IGR4) nanoengineered composite materials for energy efficient devices and applications. The Center?s research will impact society by developing novel nanomaterials to be used in improved therapies and diagnostics, cleaner and more efficient energy alternatives. In addition, the Center?s proposed activities will foster the in-corporation of Hispanics in the workforce pipeline leading to advanced degrees in engineering areas related to Nanotechnology.

Nanotechnology Center for Biomedical and Energy-Driven Systems and Applications

Center Directors: Oscar Marcelo Suárez (PI), Carlos Rinaldi, Oscar Perales, Arturo Hernández, Jeannette Santos

The Nanotechnology Center for Biomedical and Energy-Driven Systems and Applications (NCBEDSA) at the University of Puerto Rico-Mayagüez (UPRM) has been one of largest projects funded by the National Science Foundation at the University of Puerto Rico-Mayagüez (UPRM). In total the institution received $4,200,000 starting September 1, 2008 and ending August 31, 2015. The overall Center strategy sought to secure UPRM’s national competitiveness in materials engineering and nanotechnology by integrating ongoing research and education efforts in engineered nanostructured materials. NCBEDSA focused on two strategic areas for the institution and the island: biomedical and energy-driven systems. Within this framework, the NCBEDSA researchers broadened and strengthened graduate and undergraduate education throughout the institution by forming a cadre of lifelong-learning materials professionals with a robust interdisciplinary training.

Intellectual Merit: The Center has been organized into four interdisciplinary research groups (IRGs) and one interdisciplinary educational group (IEG) and originally involved 19 professors. NCBEDSA’s transformative research hinged on fundamental and applied aspects of nanomaterials encompassing:

  • IRG1 multifunctional nanoparticles for magnetically actuated siRNA delivery;
  • IRG2 quantum dot systems for cancer therapy;
  • IRG3 nanoporous materials for separations and catalysis; and
  • IRG4 nanoengineered composite materials for energy efficient devices and applications.

The nanomaterials being studied included (but were not strictly limited to): (a) magnetic nanoparticles coated with thermoresponsive block copolymers; (b) bioconjugated core-shell and Cd-free quantum dots; (d) nanoporous sorbents with sand-clock and tunable channels; (e) metal-organic frameworks with tunable surfaces; (f) multifunctional catalysts; (g) polymer-based and metal-based nanocomposites. All those novel nanomaterials were intended for improved cancer therapies and diagnostics (particularly for cancer treatment), and cleaner and more efficient energy alternatives.

IRG1 developed new nanomaterials for chemotherapeutic agents and heat and for the triggered release of therapeutic agents, both consisting of magnetic nanoparticles with functional polymer coatings and which dissipate heat under the action of an alternating magnetic field. This work has demonstrated enhanced therapeutic efficacy of anti-cancer drugs such as cisplatin when administered in combination with heat delivered by magnetic nanoparticles. These researchers demonstrated that significant reductions in cell survival can be achieved without a macroscopic perceptible temperature rise when using receptor targeted magnetic nanoparticles. IRG2 worked on materials involving photodynamic therapy (PDT). This is the interaction of a photo-sensitizer (PS) with light to cause selective damage of target tissues. Hence, only tissues exposed to light are exposed to cytotoxic reactions, reactions in the targeted cells.
